description: Illustration from the 'Gulshan-i 'Ishq (Rose Garden of Love).  A man holds a large bag of clothes seated under a tree, upper center, seven fairies playing in a pool with fountain are gesturing to him, figures surround on four sides by a garden
marks: Verso: untranslated columns of Dakani Urdu
medium: Opaque watercolors and gold on paper
text: This folio is from a manuscript made for an elite patron in the Deccan region of south India.  It illustrates a story about the trials and tribulations of lovers, a metaphor for divine love. At the center of this painting, we see one of its characters, King Raja Bikram, who sits underneath a tree in a beautiful garden. Bikram and his wife are unable to conceive a child, and thus he has embarked on a spiritual journey to find a solution. Wearing the humble outfit of a wandering mendicant, he has spied seven fairies bathing in a fountain.  He steals their clothes and holds them in a large bag, which he ransoms in order to enlist the fairiesâ€™ help. The fairies gesticulate wildly for their clothes, and agree to help Bikram find a holy man, from whom he eventually obtains a fruit that allows his wife to bear a son.
title: Raja Bikram Collecting the Clothes of the Bathing Fairies
